awd_titl_txt: Achieving the Full Phase Space of Inorganic Natural Products and Beyond in Nanocrystal Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature, through geology, has created an inspiring array of crystals with a wide range of properties (color, porosity, and mechanical strength, etc.).  The unique properties of different types of crystals are a result of not only their chemical compositions, but also the precise and specific arrangement of the constituent atoms. As nanosized crystals (of dimensions of only about 1/1000 times the width of a strand of hair), these diverse properties could lead to applications as far reaching as earth abundant and active industrial catalysts, new cancer treatments, magnetic storage media, better batteries, and inexpensive and efficient solar panels. Before any of this is possible, the routes to synthesize these crystals at the nanoscale must first be discovered because the extreme conditions of geology cannot be easily replicated in the chemistry laboratory or industrial facilities.  The research group of Professor Janet Macdonald at Vanderbilt University seeks to understand how the precise placements of atoms in nano-sized rocks can be controlled.  Experiments are designed to interrogate what happens to organic molecules and metal atoms when they react and how to control the precise placement of atoms in these nano-sized rocks.  The ultimate goal is to make all the phases of crystals that geology does, and possibly be able to design and prepare crystals with new phases. The project also examines how the surfaces of small pieces of iron oxide pigments bind to granite surfaces in the remarkably durable rock paintings of the Anishinaabe, an indigenous people of the United States and Canada. The goal here is to rediscover the lost technique for rock art and return it to the Anishinaabe. The project supports the training of researchers in high school, undergraduate and graduate student levels. Established and new connections encourage Anishinaabe researchers to take part in the research. 

Specifically, this project uses libraries of organic molecules that contain sulfur and selenium atoms as precursors to obtain the diverse crystals made of these materials. A wide, sweeping and systematic study of the phase-controlled synthesis of iron, cobalt, nickel and copper chalcogenide nanocrystals is being performed.  Libraries of organochalcogenides are employed to separate the roles of kinetic rates from the decomposition mechanisms in phase-determination. Organic reaction products are identified to decipher the mechanisms of decomposition of the organochalcogenides on the metals and deduce the impact of these mechanisms on phase control. In a second aim, organoselenol and diselenide chemistry facilitates polytypic selection in the transition metal chalcogenides. In situ solution 1H and 77Se NMR spectroscopy of nanocrystal reactions are used to understand how the organochalcogenide chemistry influences the polytypism in nanocrystal synthesis. In the final thrust, adherence of hematite pigments to silica is studied under varied application conditions precisely controlled using laboratory chemicals. Translation of these studies to naturally sourced materials follows.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Crystalline materials are the components of many important technologies including battery components, electronics, superconductors, and nano-enabled medical technologies. As nanoparticle chemists, we strive to synthesize crystals at tiny scales, to improve the function in these technologies. A key hurdle is that while it is easy to control what atoms form crystals, it is difficult to control how they arrange and order in space.  Before many new nano-enabled technologies can be achieved or improved, we have to be able to synthesize crystals at tiny scales in the atomic structures desired.

During the period of this grant, we took one of the most complex two-atom systems, the iron sulfides, and used it as a model system for discovery.  By controlling the type of sulfur reagent being used and reaction temperature, we were able to understand how to make each and every one of the iron sulfides as nanoparticles, the first time that had every been achieved. More importantly, the process of discovery gave a new way to understand how the arrangement of atoms in crystals form and change with time, which can be applied to other systems.

 We also worked with combinations of several other metals with selenium or tellurium, which are below sulfur on the periodic table and have similar, but more reactive chemistry. We learned that unique types of metal selenium and metal tellurium nanosized crystals can be formed, some never before seen. We discovered it was important to develop reagents that that give up their selenium and tellurium atoms very slowly to obtain these rare crystal types. The hope is that this knowledge will facilitate the discovery of more entirely new structures, with new exciting technologically relevant properties.

 Other crystals that don’t exist in nature can be made by building a crystal and then changing out some of the atoms. For example, we used copper sulfide, and exchanged some of the copper atoms with iron to make a mixed copper iron sulfide. It was discovered that if this process is manipulated so the rate of copper atoms coming out is similar to the rate at which iron atoms go in, the structure of the copper sulfide crystal does not change. The process is akin to the furniture being replaced in a house, with the structure of the house being retained.  This way nanocrystals of CuFeS2 were synthesized for the first time with a structure similar to Cu2S, which is not seen in nature.

In the process of this project, we learned much about iron chemistry and what happens at the surfaces of crystals. We extended this knowledge to a material and cultural question within the Anishinaabe community about their religiously important ochre (iron oxide) rock paintings. The paintings are on cliff faces overlooking lakes and rivers and have been extraordinarily resilient to weather. Unfortunately, the knowledge of how to make more paintings has been lost. We have been using our chemistry knowledge to rediscover the method for rock art making. During the tenure of this grant, we discovered that basic pH paint mixtures is likely necessary, but not sufficient part of paint formulation. The resilience of the rock paintings likely results from reactions at basic pH that give strong covalent bonds between the paint and the rock surface.
